metadata.case_name: Auction Purchaser v. Drum Manufacturing Company (First Respondent)

facts.text: Maharashtra State Finance Corporation lent Rs. 10 lakhs to first respondent (drum manufacturing private limited company) in May 1961, secured by mortgage of land, factory building, plant and machinery at Kalwa, District Thana.
Respondents 2 and 3 guaranteed repayment of the loan.
In or about 1964, Dena Bank advanced Rs. 20 lakhs to first respondent, presumably on security of plant, machinery and raw material stocks.
First respondent defaulted in repayment; Corporation issued notice under s.30 of State Financial Corporation Act, 1951 demanding discharge of liability.

Corporation filed Miscellaneous Application No. 75 of 1965 in District Court under s.31 of the Act against respondents 1,2,3 to levy dues (over Rs.16 lakhs) by attachment and sale of mortgaged properties.
In June 1966, Corporation moved for appointment of receiver to take charge of attached properties and sell by court auction; receiver appointed.
Proclamation of sale settled on December 5, 1967; sale fixed for January 8, 1968 but did not take place.
On January 11, 1966 order for sale made; judgment debtor applied for time to negotiate private sale but failed.
On January 12, 1967, Corporation applied for sale of entire unit.
Sale fixed for January 8, 1968 postponed at instance of Dena Bank as machinery not fixed to earth not shown separately.
On August 7, 1968, judgment debtor prayed for postponement to raise funds privately; Court directed deposit of Rs.1.5 lakhs by October 15, 1968 and postponed sale to last week of October.
Judgment debtor could not deposit Rs.1.5 lakhs; sale did not take place on October 29, 1968 as Corporation and Bank wanted machinery description in proclamation.
Early December 1968, judgment debtor applied for sale of whole property in one lot; turned down on December 12, 1968 as dilatory.

Judgment debtor moved High Court for stay of sale; appeal withdrawn February 26, 1969; filed suit for declaration of sale order without jurisdiction, withdrawn April 16, 1969 after injunction refused.
Sale fixed May 1, 1969 had no bidders; Mukund Iron offered Rs.2.20 lakhs for land and buildings only.
Sale on May 16, 1969: highest bids Rs.2 lakhs (land/building), Rs.80,000 (machinery); Court found too low, adjourned.
Sale on June 5, 1969: Rs.2.60 lakhs (land/building), Rs.2.10 lakhs (machinery); Court postponed for better price.
Sale on August 28, 1969: Rs.5.70 lakhs (land/building), Rs.5.40 lakhs (machinery); adjourned for valuation reports.
Corporation obtained valuation from M/s. Corona Electricals: land/buildings Rs.10,46,096, machinery Rs.7,02,000, total Rs.17,48,096; judgment debtor provided no valuation.
Auction on September 3, 1969: highest offers Rs.5,65,000 (lot 1), Rs.5,00,000 (lot 2); appellant raised to Rs.11,50,000 total; Court approved sale.

About 30-40 bidders present on August 28 and September 3, including judgment debtor's director Shri B. Paul, Dena Bank representative, Indian Oil Corporation, other industrial concerns; no objections raised by judgment debtor or Bank.
Corporation's initial valuation of assets around Rs.15 lakhs at time of s.31 application.
Executing Court (District Court) dismissed judgment debtor's application under Order XXI r.90 CPC; Bombay High Court set aside sale.
Appellant offered to pay valuation amount Rs.17,48,096 during arguments.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was any material irregularity in the conduct of the sale under Order XXI r.90 CPC and whether it caused substantial injury to the judgment debtor?

petitioner_arguments.text: No material irregularity in conduct of sale; Court exercised conscientious discretion in confirming sale at Rs.11.5 lakhs given circumstances.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Order XXI r.90 CPC; S.32 State Financial Corporation Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Multiple adjournments already made to secure better price; further postponements would deter bidders and defeat purpose.
Judgment debtor present at auctions, raised no objection; Dena Bank also present and silent.

respondent_arguments.text: Sale price inadequate compared to valuation (Rs.17.48 lakhs); Court ignored prospects of higher price with better publicity and adjournment.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Order XXI r.90 CPC; Condition 3 in proclamation of sale

respondent_arguments.text: Material irregularity in Court's acceptance of highest bid without proper consideration; rains on sale day, flaws in valuation report, etc.

court_reasoning.text: Court sale is forced sale; best price not always forthcoming; judge must consider margin for this, valuation as basis but not conclusive; specialized industrial plant out of commission limits buyers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No material irregularity; Court alert to secure fair price over multiple auctions.

court_reasoning.text: Frequent adjournments can deter bidders and undermine court sales; judgment debtor's dilatory tactics contributed to buyer hesitancy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: District Judge exercised lively discretion; no mechanical approval.

court_reasoning.text: Presence of bidders, no objections from interested parties; downward trend in bids justified closing sale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere inadequacy of price insufficient without irregularity and injury.

court_reasoning.text: Court's duty under Condition 3 and precedents to ensure reasonable price but not adjourn indefinitely; no speaking order needed if mind applied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: District Court committed no material irregularity.

holdings.text: No material irregularity in conduct of sale under Order XXI r.90 CPC causing substantial injury; sale confirmed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nayalkha and Sons vs. Ramanya Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Court's duty to satisfy itself on adequacy of price before confirmation; no vested right in highest bidder.
Appellate power to review discretion of trial court.

statutes_cited.name: State Financial Corporations Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice for repayment; application for attachment and sale; CPC applied as far as practicable for realisation.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Setting aside sale for material irregularity causing substantial injury; conditions in proclamation.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order setting aside sale reversed; District Court order dismissing application under Order XXI r.90 upheld; appellant directed to deposit balance to make total Rs.17,48,096 within two months for possession; Corporation at liberty to withdraw dues with interest.
outcome.relief_granted: Sale confirmed in favour of appellant; possession upon payment of Rs.17,48,096.
outcome.costs: Parties to bear their own costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "The condition of confirmation by the Court operates as a safeguard against the property being sold at inadequate price whether or not it is a consequence of any irregularity or fraud in the conduct of the sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains judicial duty in confirming court sales.

key_quotes.text: "Mere inadequacy of price cannot demolish every court sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on when sales can be set aside.

key_quotes.text: "What is expected of the judge is not to be a prophet but a pragmatist."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court need not predict future prices but appraise realistically.
